text: South Sudan has erupted in clashes in
the last few days that have killed
hundreds of people
this is Jeffrey gentlemen East Africa
bureau chief for the New York Times I've
been covering South Sudan for the past
ten years right now we're in a really
depressing moment the violence that is
sweeping across Juba right now is a
continuation a factional fighting that
has wracked the country since December
2013 the key players are react mature
who was the vice president of the
country and Salva Kiir who was the
president of the country they both hail
from different ethnic groups
mr. Kyra zabinga mr. Makar is a new heir
and this conflict has taken a real
ethnic direction with civilians of new
heirs and Dinkas being killed by
soldiers of the other group so nobody's
basically safe in South Sudan
not the soldiers not the civilian is not
even the peacekeepers to Chinese
peacekeepers were killed in recent days
while they were trying to protect
civilians a key question of whether this
flares up into a huge war is whether
international pressure can get the two
sides mister cures and mr. matures
to make peace one of the biggest
concerns right now are these large
internally displaced persons camps in
and around Juba many people are worried
that these camps could be attacked and
that the peacekeepers will not be able
to keep hundreds or even thousands of
soldiers from storming these camps often
these camps are predominantly one ethnic
group or another in South Sudan it's
very easy to tell who belongs to which
ethnic group both the newer and zdenka
performed traditional scarring wear on
their forehead they'll have different
patterns of lines and it's very easy
just to by looking at a man walking down
the street to tell if he is new air or
Dinka when I was in South Sudan a few
months ago I was in one of these
displaced persons camps and it was full
of new heirs who had fled violence and
were very worried that they were going
to be targeted by Dinka soldiers
and I remember talking to one young man
and he pointed to his forehead and he
said these scars are essentially my
death certificate if I step outside
people will know I'm nowhere and they
could attack me so that's how dire the
situation really is and that's why
people are really frightened because
there's a pattern of violence in this
place
Oh
